subject: Barf
event:
Life is miserable and full of pain.

Giants look utterly wretched.  A few good plans from JPP, and maybe we have a new TE emerging.  Nothing else good can be said.  They were humiliated by the Cardinals, with a backup QB.  C'mon.

Jets took a 21-3 lead and still figured out a way to piss it away.  Harassed Aaron Rodgers and sacked him repeatedly, still allowed him to complete the big passes and runs when it counted.  Geno, meanwhile, put up some nice stats early on, but can never seem to make the key throw when the game is on the line.  Well, no, to be fair, he did complete one great pass in crunch time... a TD which was called back when a coach who did not actually have the power to call a time-out somehow called a time-out.  Needless to say, Geno's attempt to duplicate the heroics a few minutes later ended in an INT.

Eli and Geno led the NFL in INTs last year, and both of them are on track to do it again.

And the Cowboys and Patriots both won big, so I don't even have that as solace.

Pfui.

comments.upictitle: Melissa aka Erin: saints black and gold
comments.article: It was not a good day for football. The Saints have lost two in a row now.

At least Buffalo is atop the AFC East. Alas this will probably not last but with Buffalo being there the Pats are not. I think that you should write off the Giants this year, they will only be a disappointment week in and week out. The Jets did show some promise they only have to play 4 quarters instead of 2.
comments.subject: Buffalo

comments.article:
As someone who is not a football fan, but has grown up less than thirty minutes away from Green Bay, I feel obligated to articulate the following message.

*ahem*

YEEEEEEEEEEEEEAAAAAAAAAAAAH! GO PACK GO!

I apologize.
comments.subject: Obligatory response from Wisconsin

comments.article: Yeah, I can relate - high hopes from beating the Pats last week were dashed when we were humiliated by the Bills this week, an inter-conference rival, *and* we lost our star running back at the start of the game. *sigh*
Years of heartbreak have kept me from following the fins very much lately. Grew up with my parents telling me about the glory days of the 70s, but I have yet to experience that. Sad.
Sorry George! But I really enjoyed my Packers big won tonight! However, I was rooting for the Giants and felt that let down!  Better luck next week I suppose.

Typical Chargers...Crap one week, gold the next. If we could just be a little more consistent we could be great. But I will enjoy this one for sure. Even I doubted our chances of beating the champs but we dominated them so, hip hip hoo-ray!

What the hell is going on with the Giants btw...? I heard during preaseason about the offensive woes but damn, they look awful.
comments.subject: Nice win for the Bolts!

comments.article:
I was pleasantly surprised to see the Cowboy's coaching staff commit to the run. Controlling the ball (and the clock) helped to cover their most glaring weaknesses: defense and pass protection.

Knowing that this week's opponent (Tennessee) was not nearly as formidable as last's (San Fran) and knowing the Cowboys proclivity for ripping my heart out with a late season collapse, I find it difficult to feel anything beyond guarded optimism.
comments.subject: Guarded Optimism

comments.article: Well George, at least one team from New York won today - the Buffalo Bills! It's not too late to start cheering for them this year.
comments.subject: NY

comments.article: ugh. that nonsense with the jets timeout thing was INFURIATING.

Just think 2007.

As for the Jets...

Dear George, I have one question for you about your book, the name for the character Stanis Baratheon, you borrowed from Prince Pyotr Bagration? Who was the best Russian general in the words Napoleon.
Sorry to offtop.
No
Er, sorry - um, you're talking about sport, right? I'm afraid I have no idea what you mean! :-(
Well, having said that, although the Jets lost in a very Jet-like manner, I have the feeling Geno is turning a corner. So there is a silver lining there.
comments.subject: Geno

comments.article:
Well, I am becoming more and more convinced that the team who played the first half of our first game this season was a group of doppelgangers who dropped out of the time/space continuum for just 30 minutes. Now they have returned to their own time/space and are on their way to winning that AU's Super Bowl equivalent.

Alas...

BTW, the talking heads on ESPN seemed to think Ryan did indeed call for the time out in question. Maybe he just was having a hand spasm?
comments.subject: Jags Fan

comments.article: The Bills are only keeping the top spot warm until the Pats need to re-claim it. :)
Couldn't agree more.  Can't believe the greatest novelist of our time is a GIANTS/JETS fan.  I mean, come on, Mr. Martin ;)
comments.subject: Enjoy it while you can, Buffalo

comments.article:
I only hope the 2014 jets season doesn't bod as poor for our favorite characters as the 1999 jets season did for the King in the North.

On a side note, thanks for the books and Jean Cocteau! You've done amazing work with both.
comments.subject: Another Red Wedding in the Making?

comments.article: Not that it makes anyone feel better, but Geno didn't throw a late pick to end the game.  It was merely an incomplete pass on 4th down that put the final nail in the coffin.  The INT came before halftime.

It is a time of hope. No fumbles, injuries or bad calls have turned our heroes to goats. No cold bucket of reality has washed away our fan fantasy.

Letâ€™s savor the moment as Faulkner said the south forever savors the moment before Picket's charge...

Oh Rams and Falcons let hope carry you forth on a fans never dampened tidal wave of wishful thinking.

That at least was my intended post for last week. But now cold reality has arrived, the all offense no defense Falcons have met with a quality NFL team and the cold logic of NFL football has pulled away the curtain. We are still hoping for better than last year's 4-12.


TomT
comments.subject: Reality Check

comments.article: Pity New York pigskin this season, the teams don't even have a good QB controversy to keep things entertaining. The footballs were berry berry good to me this weekend. Cleaned up in my NFL pick 'em league and laid the lumber on ECU as a six-point dog to Virginia Tech. Got a nice cushion to see me through my idiotic picks that are sure to come. Berry berry good indeed.
Another miserable year of sports in the NYC... *bangs head into wall*
comments.subject: I just can't...

comments.article: My team lost to the Rams and their third string quarterback. At home! Even you Mr. Martin wouldn't write a story that depressing.

Trying to look on the bright side, but after Sunday I feel confident that the offense at least will be much better than last year. Thought Eli played his best game in a while, and Donnell and Jennings add two components that were missing from last years team. Add to that, Eli getting more comfortable in the new system with each week and I might be able to actually watch this team without wanting to tear all my hair out.

I'm going to predict a win against the Texans next week.
comments.subject: Glass Half Full

comments.article: And my hometown team, the Chiefs, have lost 7 starters. Why do I feel I should qualify that with a "so far"? And of course they're 0-2.
comments.subject: Heck of a season, isn't it?

comments.article: I hate to ask but.   Will you consider a one season boycott of the NFL?  I am a lifelong fan and its the one sport I truly love.  But this year it is so important, to show the NFL that it cannot hide abuses within its ranks any more.  I am tired of hearing about them.  Giant men, hard as rocks, stamina and strength like no others.  Our gladiators.  They should be confident and chivalrous.  But instead I see abuse of the tiny woman.  The NFL made a terrible mistake trying to hide this.  Giving Ray Rice a 2 game suspension was the last straw for me.  Then they lied about seeing the video.  This is terrible.  My ex-husband was an wife-abuser who loved football.  Write an open letter to the NFL.  Tell them how stupid it is to hide abuse.  Tell them you will boycott for one season.  For all the woman and children who may be knocked out or even killed by these huge men.  Thanks for considering my request.  Traci Bear
comments.subject: Boycott of NFL

comments.article: Seconded.
comments.subject: Re: Boycott of NFL

comments.article: Bob Wischusen after the game said: "Greg, we've seen them lose on penalties. We've seen them lose on turnovers. We've seen them lose on bad decisions. I've never seen a team lose like that." That's the Jets right there. Pioneering new ways to lose. And Wischusen could have also said, "I've seen them lose due to clock mismanagement. I've seen them lose from mental mistakes. I've seen them lose because they'd lost that way before and so it was inevitable." And after having season tickets for 15 years, I've seen most of those games live. Why do I do this to myself week after week?
comments.subject: Pioneers
